The Ultimate Low-Quality Image Placeholder Technique â€” Harry notes the importance in offering a reasonably pleasant experience for users who find themselves waiting for images to load, explaining how Low-Quality Image Placeholders (LQIP) are one such possible answer. The problem however is they donâ€™t particularly play nice with Core Web Vitals and Largest Contentful Paint (LCP). This post goes into any nuances to be aware of, along with how best to implement aÂ solution.

Harry Roberts

How Photoshop is Now on the Web â€” Getting Photoshop onto the Web (where it has been for a little while now â€“ we first covered Photoshop's journey to the Web in 2021) was the result of both a lot of collaboration and a myriad of modern browser technologies (WebAssembly, Web Components + Lit, Service Workers & more) that Addy covers in thisÂ post.

Addy Osmani

And itâ€™s our people who make us remarkable. Our success is your success. Letâ€™s celebrate together. LearnÂ more.

Bosch sponsor

Chrome for Developers

FranÃ§ois Beaufort

Using The Intl Segmenter API â€” Kilian shared on Twitter that he lost some time â€œtrying to detect words in non-western language stringsâ€ but then learnt about the Intl.segmenter browser API. It has a ton of functionality for editing and formatting of text and numbers. This post shows us how to useÂ it.

Kilian Valkhof

Eric Eggert

Can be used in a vanilla fashion or with integrations for React orÂ Vue.js.

Simon Reinisch

blog-cells: Add Runnable, Interactive Code Snippets onÂ Pages â€” Like embedding a JSFiddle or Codepen, but these are a cleaner and minimal solution that work well in tutorials and in SSGs like Jekyll or Hugo. Try some examplesÂ here.

Varun Ramesh

MiniSim: A Native Mac Menubar App for Launching iOS and Android Emulators â€” Itâ€™s open source, includes various configuration settings for a handy mobile testingÂ solution.

Oskar KwaÅ›niewski

Sprite Your SVGs: Paste SVG Code to Generate an OptimizedÂ Sprite â€” CSS sprites arenâ€™t so much of a thing nowadays, but if you have a use case for an SVG sprite, this helps with the codeÂ generation.

JosÃ© Donato

Atrament.js: A Library for Smooth Drawing on HTML Canvas â€” Demo.

items.title: What do you think about HTML in 2023?
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹611 â€” September 27, 2023 | Read on the web

Take the State of HTML 2023 Survey (and Change theÂ Web) â€” A new survey from the folks behind State of JavaScript and State of CSS. This is a natural companion to the other two surveys and should result in a more complete overview of the web platform as a whole. We encourage everyone to fill it out as answers submitted by October 1 will be used to inform this year's Interop 2024 proposals. Lea Verou outlines how this survey came to be and what you need to know. We'll share the results too, in dueÂ course.

Devographics

Cloudflare Fonts: Enhancing Web Font Privacy and Speed â€” A new one-click service coming to Cloudflare users that means sites using Google Fonts will be able to load the fonts from their own domain rather than fromÂ Google and reduce the number of round trips from eight toÂ one.

Bullock and Woodhead (Cloudflare)

CSS Foundations with Emma Bostian â€” This extensive video course will help you nail the CSS essentials. You'll learn core terminology, practical skills (such as Flexbox and Grid), and gain hands-on experience â€” all of which will equip you with the fundamentals required for creating professional responsiveÂ sites.

Frontend Masters sponsor

The Path to Awesome CSS Easing with linear() â€” The new CSS linear() easing function is on the horizon, expanding what we can do when it comes to creating more natural-feeling animations and transitions. This post looks at what the current state of CSS easing is and demonstrates what we can expect from linear() once itÂ lands.

Jhey Tompkins

Why HTTP/3 is Eating the World â€” What problems HTTP/3 solves, how it performs, why itâ€™s seen such swift adoption, and what limitations it's still working toÂ overcome.

Robin Marx

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Todayâ€™s Google Doodle celebrates 25 years of the search giant.

  • Firefox 118 is out now and includes automated translation of web content. The general release notes are here, with the developer information here.

  • â–¶ï¸ A video outlining what's new in version 1.38 of web testing and automation framework Playwright.

  • Ben Hawkes goes deep into a significant WebP related security vulnerability that could allow out of bounds memory writes via a specially crafted HTML page. More discussionÂ here.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

The Design System Ecosystem â€” This post goes deep into the weeds on a â€˜layer-cake approachâ€™ to creating robust, mature design systems. Of course, the advice isnâ€™t one size fits all, but thereâ€™s plenty of good takeawaysÂ here.

Brad Frost

Responsive Type Scales with Composable CSS Utilities â€” With the help of calc(), clamp() and CSS vars, we can create composable, responsive, and fluid type scales that smoothly adapts to viewport and containerÂ widths.

Tobias Ahlin Bjerrome

Debugging Errors Faster with Distributed Tracing â€” Join us October 17, to learn how distributed tracing helps uncover elusive bugs & performance problems inÂ microservices.

Sentry sponsor

'Web Push Is Almost Usable with iOS 17' â€” â€œwith enough dedication and grit, you can get push notifications to show up on iOS devices, and itâ€™s a little easier with iOSÂ 17â€

Matt Steele

â–¶Â Â CSS Terminology Demystified â€” A 5 minute video to help you talk more confidently about CSS terminology, such as declarations, statements, etc.

Zoran Jambor beginner

Your Cache Headers Could Probably be More Aggressive â€” A look at what we can do to push cache performance (for some assets) evenÂ further.

Alex MacArthur

â–¶Â Â Accessibility Is Easy â€¦ Except for When It Isnâ€™t â€” A half-hour look at how to approach making complicated UIs accessible using standard techniques and a â€œlittle more creativeÂ thinkingâ€.

Ian Lloyd

Solved by CSS Scroll-Driven Animations: Detect if an Element Can Scroll or Not
Bramus Van Damme

What Can You Do with data- Attributes?
Chris Ferdinandi

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» JOBS

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

ChatGPT.js: A JavaScript Library for Working with ChatGPT'sÂ DOM â€” Includes a fairly extensive API that lets you interact with ChatGPT for use in Chrome extensions, Tampermonkey scripts, and soÂ on. Take note of the rather in-your-face design of this page - wow!Â ğŸ˜…

KudoAI

Mimic.css: A CSS Animation Library of Unique Animations â€” Not a new project but we can almost guarantee these are animations you havenâ€™t seen before! Examples here, where you can try out lawn mower, candle in the wind, drop it like itâ€™s hot, andÂ more.

Eric Treacy

Repo Trends: View and Analyze Trends in GitHub Repository Issues Over Time â€” A nicely designed tool that displays visual data for open issues and pull requests on a given GitHubÂ repository.

Steve Sanders

Media-Card-Web-Component: A Web Component to Fetch Details on Books, Movies, Music, etc. â€” This will tap into various third-party APIs for Open Library, iTunes, The Movie Database, and so on, to display media and info for the requested item. ExamplesÂ here.

Marketing Pipeline

little-rat: A Chrome Extension to Monitor (and Optionally Block) Other Extensions' Network Calls

Daniel Nakov

Swup: A Flexible Page Transition Library for Server-Side Rendered Sites â€” A library that benefits hugely from checking out the demos. v4.4 adds experimental ViewTransition support.

Georgy Marchuk

ğŸ•° ICYMI (Some older stuff that's still worth checking out)

  • Dipika Bhattacharya explains how the CSS :not() pseudo-class behaves when multiple selectors are passed as an argument.

  • Ben Edelstein highlights an industrial supply website that you likely haven't heard of, and what smart design choices it makes. We love it.

  • SVG symbols allow you to declare an SVG element once per page and reuse it many times without losing web performance. Bart Stefanski looks at whether they actually significantly boost speed or not.

  • Dave Rupert shares how to get started with View Transitions on multi-pageÂ apps.

items.title: Safari 17 is here
items.content:
ğŸ‘‹ Hello! This week we've asked Ahmad Shadeed to share a few of his favorite frontend tools. Be sure to scroll down and see them.
__
Chris Brandrick, Editor

ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹610 â€” September 20, 2023 | Read on the web

WebKit Features in Safari 17.0 â€” Safari 17.0 is now available for both iOS 17 and iPadOS 17, it will arrive on macOS a little later this month. This release is packed, and includes support for the <search> element, the popover attribute, the CSS font-size-adjust property, the Storage API, JPEG XL, and much more. BigÂ release!

Jen Simmons and the WebKit team

v0: Using AI to Build Frontend Components? â€” An interesting experiment from Vercel where you submit prompts like â€œa country selection fieldâ€ or â€œa contact formâ€ and it returns copy/paste-able shadcn/ui + Tailwind CSS code. Itâ€™s in â€œprivate alphaâ€ for now, but you can take a good look at how it worksÂ here. A sign of theÂ future?

Vercel Labs

The Complete UI Component Library For Enterprise Web Apps â€” A professional UI component library with power widgets like data grid, calendar, scheduler & Gantt charts. Includes API docs, guides and an unreasonable amount of demos to play with. Seamlessly integrates with React, Angular, Vue & SalesforceÂ apps.

Bryntum sponsor

free-for.dev: A Bumper List of Stuff That's 'Free' for Developers â€” An interesting and extensive list of hosted services or otherwise paid-for products that have free tiers or options for developers. We linked to this a couple of years ago but it has been updated a lotÂ since.

R.I.Pienaar

A (More) Modern CSS Reset â€” Andy created a modern CSS reset almost four years ago, but itâ€™s time for an update to, well, keep itÂ modern.

Andy Bell

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • WordPress blogs can now be followed in the fediverse.

  • ğŸ“… CodeWord is an upcoming free online event (tomorrow) looking at how developers interact with content in their code. Speakers include Chris Coyier, Cassisy Williams, Miriam Schwab, and others.

  • Browser company Vivaldi has penned an open letter to the EU Commission to express "concerns over Microsoftâ€™s anti-competitive practices" in regards to Edge.

  • Figma-friendly design tool Anima now has Tailwind CSS support.

  • â™– Opera is releasing a 'special edition' of their browser, with built-in..Â chess?

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Get All That Network Activity Under Control with Priority Hints â€” Alex notes how the browser is pretty good at prioritizing resources requests on its own, but itâ€™s not perfect. He shows us how priority hints makes it easy to provide explicit instructions, and just what scenarios theyâ€™re most helpfulÂ in.

Alex MacArthur

More CSS Findings from the Threads App â€” Ahmad continues his spelunking into Metaâ€™s new social network, revealing a few interesting CSS findings from the Threads webÂ app.

Ahmad Shadeed

How to Adjust Image Size Without Distortion | AI-Powered Smart Resize â€” This feature allows you to automate image resizing without losing quality or distorting objects in aÂ picture.

Uploadcare sponsor

Revealing ImagesÂ withÂ CSS MaskÂ Animations â€” A look at combining various CSS masks to create fancy image hover transitions/reveals. There's lots of visual demos and codeÂ examples here.

Temani Afif

A Beginnerâ€™s Guide to Using Pico CSS â€” An overview of getting started with this slimlineÂ framework.

David Uzondu

Counting Ghosts: A Case for Abandoning Web Analytics
P.C. Maffey

Web Apps are Better Than No Apps
Yury Molodtsov

ğŸ” FIVE IN FOCUS with Ahmad Shadeed

Five frontend recommendations from Ahmad Shadeed, design engineer, writer at ishadeed.com, and author of Debugging CSS.

  1. Stylelint
    This is a CSS linter that helps me avoid CSS mistakes upfront.
  2. Open Props
    I like this a lot because it gives us the power of Tailwind, but with pure CSS variables.
  3. Browser DevTools
    This is my most used tool while building stuff, it's opened by default.
  4. Responsive Viewer Extension
    Adds responsive testing in the browser (Chrome) with a click of a button.
  5. Codepen

ğŸ” FIVE IN FOCUS with Chris Coyier

Five recommendations from Chris Coyier, co-founder of popular social development environment CodePen, and co-host of the ShopTalk podcast.

  1. CleanShot X
    Really great macOS-specific screenshot & screencast recording tool. This is a somewhat crowded market, but the feature set and polish of CleanShot X makes it a clear standout to me. I use it a dozen times a day I bet. I like that it comes in Setapp, because it helps make that subscription a no-brainer to me. Setapp has other indispensable tools for me, like TablePlus, Paste, BusyCal, and Sip.
  2. Feedbin
    The finest RSS reader app out there. One feature shoutout: giving an email address to send email newsletters to, so those can be read where they belong, with other written publications.
  3. CSS Pro
    Nice little browser extension that gives you a bunch of designer-y tools on any website for screwing around with the site immediately. Itâ€™s great for playing around and prototyping. But my favorite is that in one click you can sent just a selected element and all itâ€™s styles over to CodePen and play in code there.
  4. gradient.style
    A nicely done CSS gradient construction tool, that includes all the types of gradients that are possible unlike so many older ones. There are nice examples, nice interactive controls, and as an important bonus: a high dynamic range color picker, so you can pick colors in OKLCH and OKLAB which are fantastic for gradients and making colors pop.
  5. Elk
    Iâ€™m grateful that such an nice web client for Mastodon exists.

Scroll-Driven Animations Debugger: A DevTools Extension â€” A new Chrome DevTools extension specifically to visualize and debug scroll-drivenÂ animations.

Bramus Van Damme

unpic/placeholder: A Library for Generating Pure CSS Image Placeholders â€” This is done by extracting the dominant color from an image or by server-side rendering a BlurHash value, which then is used to display a temporary image during loadÂ time.

Matt Kane

qr-code: Web Component for Animatable SVG-Based QRÂ Codes â€” Weâ€™re not entirely sure why youâ€™d want to animate a QR code, but the effects are pretty neat. You can try out the demoÂ here.

Jason Dreyzehner

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity â€” Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Read the docsÂ now.

Userfront sponsor

CSS Loaders: A Collection of 500+ Loading Animations â€” This is a huge collection of animated single-element CSS-only loaders. Youâ€™re bound to find one that suits your projectÂ here.

Temani Afif

BlendIcons: 140K+ Free Icons in Various Categories and Styles â€” A simple UI lets you search via keyword and you can filter by icon styles (bold, filled, etc.). Each icon is available in different formats including SVG, PNG, JSX, CSS, HTML, Base64, etc.

Blendicons

Crop Video: Online Tool to Quickly Crop a Video File â€” From Adobe Express, this tool gives you pre-built crop settings for landscape, portrait (i.e. for TikTok), square, or just do itÂ freeform.

Adobe Express

React Plock: A 1KB Masonry Grid Component â€” TypeScript-ready and itâ€™s easy to customize the grid columns and rows for responsive layouts in the style ofÂ Unsplash,Â say.

Renato Pozzi

Run Lighthouse on PageSpeed Insights Against a Set of URLs â€” You'll need Node.js, but this will let you see which of the sites you supply is fastest. In other words, something like â€œAmazing Raceâ€ forÂ websites?

Zach Leatherman
